questions.text: A 62-year-old man complained to his physician of facial grimacing, lip smacking, and rocking of the trunk that occurred 1 to 2 hours after taking his prescribed medication. The man, who suffered from Parkinson disease, had been receiving an anti-parkinson drug for more than 3 years. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the adverse effects reported by the patient?
questions.solution:
The adverse effects reported by the patient and the timing of the effects suggest that they are levodopa-induced dyskinesias, which occur in up to 80% of patients receiving the drug for long periods.

  • The development of dyskinesias is dose-related, and dyskinesias are usually associated with peak striatal dopamine levels or when the level of the drug is rising or falling.
  • The exact mechanism of these dyskinesias is not known, but simplistically it can be thought of as too much movement caused by too much striatal dopamine receptor stimulation.

Option A: Selegiline is a dopamine metabolism inhibitor. This drug can be given in combination with levodopa + carbidopa to decrease the dose of levodopa (and thus decrease abnormal movements).

Option C: Entacapone is a dopamine metabolism inhibitor. This drug can be given in combination with levodopa + carbidopa to decrease the dose of levodopa (and thus decrease abnormal movements).

Option D: Recently approved for treating Levodopa induced Dyskinesia as Amantadine acts as a NMDA Antagonist (Only anti Parkinsonian drug to treat dyskinesia).

Key Takeaway:

  • levodopa-induced dyskinesias is dose-related, and dyskinesias are usually associated with peak striatal dopamine. It can be Treated with Amantadine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of food poisoning presented to the emergency department with multiple episodes of vomiting, mild diarrhea and weakness. He was given an intravenous drug to control the severity of vomiting and later he developed abnormal posture as given in the image below. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonia:

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles - grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most during treatment with Dopaminergic antagoinist therapy.
  • Here mostly Metoclopramide is given as an anti-emetic drug and as it is dopaminergic antagonist it has created acute dystonia as side effect.
  • One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Central anticholinergics:

  • The central anticholinergics act by reducing the unbalanced cholinergic activity in the striatum of parkinsonian patients.
  • Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug (phenothiazines, other D2 antagonists) induced parkinsonism.

Option A: Levodopa, Prodrug of Dopamine is not Effective in Muscular Dystonia.

Option C: Ondansetron, 5HT3 Antagonist antiemetic is not effective in Muscular Dystonia.

Option D: Selegiline, MAO Inhibitor reduces metabolism of Monoamines but is not effective in acute muscular dystonia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug induced parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man brought to his physician with complaints of pin rolling tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Later he was diagnosed as having Parkinson's disease and prescribed L-dopa as first medicine. Which of the following is the most common dose limiting adverse effect of L-dopa?
questions.solution:
• The most common limiting adverse effect of L-dopa is dyskinesia that may occur in up to 90 percent of patients.
  • L-dopa induced dyskinesias worsen with time and practically all patients get involved after few years.
  • Their intensity corresponds with levodopa levels.
  • No tolerance develops to this adverse effect, but dose reduction decreases severity.
  • Abnormal movements may become as disabling as the original disease itself, and are the most important dose-limiting side effects.
  • Orthostatic hypotension, depression, and nausea are also adverse effects, but can be more readily managed and tolerated by patients.

Key Takeaway:

  • Abnormal movements(dyskinesia) are the most important dose-limiting side effects of L-dopa.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with Parkinsonism was on medication for the same. Later he presented to emergency department with swollen red, tender and very painful feet (as shown in the given figure below). Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Amantadine can Cause ankle edema (reversible) and Livedo reticularis (Pinkish pigmentation of skin in form of meshwork) as shown in the image above.

Livedo reticularis

  • A characteristic side effect due to local release of CAs resulting in postcapillary vasoconstriction is livedo reticularis (bluish discolouration) and edema of ankles.
  • Side effects are accentuated when amantadine is combined with anticholinergics.

Drugs Increasing Dopamine Level at Synapse

  • Amantadine is an antiviral drug that is also useful in Parkinsonism.
  • It increases synaptic dopamine level by increasing presynaptic release and decreasing its reuptake.
  • It also possesses anticholinergic and antiglutaminergic (NMDA blocking) activity.
  • Adverse effects of this drug include nausea, insomnia, ankle edema and livedo reticularis.
  • It is indicated for treatment of dyskinesia associated with chronic levodopa therapy.

Option A, C & D: All other agents are not associated with development of livedo reticularis as side effect

Key Takeaway:

  • Amantadine can Cause ankle edema and Livedo reticularis (Pinkish pigmentation of skin in form of meshwork)

questions.text: A 53-year-old diabetic woman complained to her physician of unpleasant, crawling discomfort sensations in her legs when she was lying down. The sensation urged the woman to move about and walking relieved her symptoms. She also complained of difficulty falling asleep and interrupted nocturnal sleep. A preliminary diagnosis of restless leg syndrome was made, and a therapy was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
Restless legs syndrome (RLS)

  • It is a condition that causes an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, usually because of an uncomfortable sensation.
  • It typically happens in the evening or night hours when a person is sitting or lying down. Moving eases the unpleasant feeling temporarily. It is also known as Ekbom syndrome
  • The disorder can occur in isolation but is more common during pregnancy, chronic renal or liver failure, iron deficiency anemia, or diabetes
  • The cause of the disorder is unclear but may involve abnormalities in dopamine neurotransmission in the central nervous system.
  • Ropinirole, rotigotine and pramipexole are approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of moderate to severe RLS.
  • Gabapentin and pregabalin may work for some people with RLS.
  • Opioids can relieve mild to severe symptoms, but they may be addicting if used in high doses.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pramipexole is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe Restless legs syndrome (RLS)

questions.text: A 78-year-old man had been showing increasing memory impairment and recognition deficits over the past 2 years. Recently, he became disoriented and confused at night. Physical examination revealed an alert person oriented to place with no focal neurologic deficits. His physician prescribed a drug that might help to slow the progression of his symptoms. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The man was most likely in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD).
  • He displayed several symptoms associated with dementia, including impaired reasoning (recognition deficits), loss of memory, confusion, and disorientation.
  • A major approach to the treatment of Alzheimer's disease has involved the attempt to augment the cholinergic function in the brain, because a loss of cholinergic neurons is a prominent feature of the disease.
  • Donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine are cholinesterase inhibitors approved for treatment of Alzheimer's disease

Key Takeaway:

  • Donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine are cholinesterase inhibitors approved for treatment of Alzheimer disease

questions.text: A 37-year-old female patient prescribed risperidone for schizophrenia. Later she was brought to the emergency room with an upward fixed gaze & bizarre muscle spasms. Which of the following is the best agent to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonias

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles-grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most during treatment with Dopaminergic antagonist therapy.
  • One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.
  • It is more common in children below 10 years and in girls, particularly after parenteral administration; overall incidence is 2%. It lasts for one to a few hours and then resolves spontaneously.

Option B: Lorazepam, BZD Group Medication not used for acute muscular dystonia.

Option C: Carbamazepine, An Antiepileptic medication not used for acute muscular dystonia.

Option D: Phenytoin, An Antiepileptic medication not used for acute muscular dystonia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine is the drug of choice for acute muscular dystonia which occurs due to Dopamine receptors blockade.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man complained to his psychiatrist of abnormal growth of his breast. The man had been receiving a psychotropic drug for 6 months to treat paranoid schizophrenia. He was medication-compliant and his illness was well controlled. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the adverse effect reported by the patient?
questions.solution:
The history and the symptoms of the patient indicate that he was most likely suffering from gynecomastia due to a neuroleptic with D2 antagonist activity, such as haloperidol.

By blocking D2 receptors, neuroleptics prevent the inhibitory effect of dopamine on prolactin secretion, thus causing hyperprolactinemia. High prolactin plasma levels can in turn cause amenorrhea/galactorrhea in women and gynecomastia in men.

Option A: Clozapine causes agranulocytosis and seizures as rare major adverse effects. Agranulocytosis is dose independent whereas seizures are dose dependent.

Option B: Amitriptyline is associated with Sedation, Weight gain and lowering the seizure threshold. Most TCAs possess powerful anticholinergic and weak α blocking properties.

Option D: Prominent side effects of venlafaxine are nausea, sweating, anxiety, dizziness, impotence and withdrawal reactions on discontinuation, aka Discontinuation syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

  • Haloperidol by blocking D2 receptors prevents the inhibitory effect of dopamine on prolactin secretion, thus causing hyperprolactinemia which can cause amenorrhea/galactorrhea in women and gynecomastia in men.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman recently diagnosed with undifferentiated schizophrenia started treatment with haloperidol. Which of the patient's presenting symptoms was most likely best controlled after 1 week of therapy with haloperidol?
questions.solution:
Positive symptoms of schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized behavior, etc.) are usually better controlled by typical neuroleptic drugs than negative symptoms

Schizophrenia:

The antipsychotics are used primarily in functional psychoses.

Typical and atypical antipsychotics are equally efficacious against positive symptoms

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Disorganized thought
  • Restlessness
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Fighting
  • Aggression

Negative symptoms are better controlled with the atypical ones

  • Apathy
  • Loss of insight and volition
  • Emotional blunting
  • Affective flattening
  • Poverty of speech
  • Social withdrawal

Option A: Social Withdrawal is Negative symptom of schizophrenia better controlled with atypical antipsychotics.

Option B: Lack of emotion is Negative symptom of schizophrenia better controlled with atypical antipsychotics.

Option C: Low Energy is a Negative symptom of schizophrenia better controlled with atypical antipsychotics.

Key Takeaway:

  • Positive symptoms of schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized behavior, etc.) are usually better controlled by typical neuroleptic drugs than negative symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient brought to Psychiatrist was recently diagnosed with schizophrenia with positive as well as negative symptoms. His psychiatrist has prescribed an appropriate medicine for him. Which of the following agents below is an antipsychotic that can improve both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Risperidone is a unique dual-acting antipsychotic agent that is an antagonist at both D2 receptors and 5-HT2 receptors and is effective in treating both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Risperidone

  • Atypical antipsychotic whose activity has been ascribed to a Combination of D2 + 5-HT2 receptor blockade.
  • In addition, it has high affinity for α1, α2 and H1 receptors: blockade of these may contribute to efficacy as well as side effects like postural hypotension.
  • Risperidone is a more potent D2 blocker than clozapine; extrapyramidal side effects are less only at low doses. Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during risperidone therapy.
  • Weight gain and incidence of new-onset diabetes is less than with clozapine and it is often selected as the first line drug in schizophrenia now.

Option A, B & C: All are older, typical antipsychotics that block dopamine receptors (among other receptors) but with no appreciable affinity for 5-HT receptors.

Key Takeaway:

  • Risperidone is a unique dual-acting antipsychotic agent that is an antagonist at both D2 receptors and 5-HT2 receptors and is effective in treating both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man complained to his physician of irritability, apathy, and the appearance of flicking movements of his extremities. He was referred to a neurologic clinic, where a diagnosis of Huntington's chorea was made. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to suppress, at least partially, his choreic movements and agitated behaviour?
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative genetic disorder that affects muscle coordination and leads to cognitive decline and dementia.

The disease seems to result from functional overactivity in dopaminergic nigrostriatal pathways.

Choreic movements and agitation can be partially suppressed by neuroleptics, such as haloperidol, probably because of their antidopaminergic activity.

Haloperidol is the preferred drug for following disorders:

  • Acute schizophrenia,
  • Huntington's disease and
  • Gilles de La Tourette's syndrome.

Option A, B & C: All other agents are not effective in chorea disorder because they lack anti-dopaminergic activity.

Key Takeaway:

  • Choreic movements and agitation can be partially suppressed by neuroleptics such as haloperidol, probably because of their antidopaminergic activity

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man suffering from severe depression was brought to the emergency department after an overdose of an unknown medication. Physical examination showed a lethargic patient with dilated pupils. Vital signs were blood pressure 95/55 mm Hg, heart rate 130 bpm, respirations 10/min.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed tachycardia with wide QRS complex (as shown in the image below). Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The history and signs of the patient suggest that he took a toxic dose of a tricyclic antidepressant.
  • These drugs have pronounced
    • Antimuscarinic activity causing mydriasis and tachycardia &
    • Antiadrenergic activity (low blood pressure) and prolong the QT interval on ECG by a quinidine-like action.
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors.

Acute poisoning: Poisoning with TCAs is frequent; usually self-attempted for suicide

Manifestations are:

  • Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma.
  • Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, tachycardia is prominent.
  • ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment is primarily supportive with

  • Gastric lavage,
  • Respiratory assistance,
  • Fluid infusion,
  • Maintenance of blood pressure and
  • Body temperature.

Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.

Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.

Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/lidocaine may be used.

Option A, B & C: All other agents don't show sign and symptoms as given above.

Key Takeaway

  • The presenting signs of a TCA overdose include cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, and anticholinergic signs (hyperthermia, flushing, dilated pupils, intestinal ileus, urinary retention, and sinus tachycardia).
  • Central nervous system signs, such as confusion, delirium, and hallucinations, typically occur before the onset of seizures or coma.
  • Cardiotoxic effects are responsible for the mortality in TCA overdose.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man came to a psychiatrist with recently diagnosed generalized anxiety disorder for treatment. He was later started an appropriate therapy with a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin. A psychotropic drug inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin is likely to cause which of the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• SSRIs offer several advantages over TCAs:
    • No anticholinergic adverse effects
    • No sedation or weight gain
    • No propensity to cause seizures or arrhythmias
  • But they cause inhibition of ejaculation and anorgasmia.

Key Takeaway:

  • SSRI typically cause inhibition of ejaculation and anorgasmia (Sexual dysfunction)

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was admitted to psychiatric ward for an eating disorder with a 3-month history of binge eating and vomiting and purging episodes occurring from twice per week. After physical examination and laboratory tests, psychotherapy and a drug treatment were prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's history and symptoms indicate that she was affected by bulimia nervosa, a chronic disorder with multiple episodes of relapse and remission that usually occurs in late adolescence.
  • Antidepressants are considered drugs of choice for bulimia nervosa.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the preferred agents because of their tolerability

SSRIs offer several advantages over TCAs:

  • No anticholinergic adverse effects
  • No sedation or weight gain
  • No propensity to cause seizures or arrhythmias

The SSRIs are now 1st choice drugs for

  • Obsessive compulsive buying
  • Panic disorder
  • Social phobia
  • Eating disorders
  • Premenstrual dysmorphic disorder
  • Post traumatic stress disorder
  • Anxiety disorders
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Compulsive buying
  • Kleptomania
  • Premature ejaculation.

Option A, B & C: All other agents don't show any efficacy in eating disorder

Key Takeaway:

  • Antidepressants are considered drugs of choice for bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man recently diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder started an appropriate therapy with a drug that acts by increasing the availability of both norepinephrine and serotonin in the synaptic cleft of central nervous system neurons. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Venlafaxine is currently a first-line agent for anxiety disorders.
  • The drug blocks both norepinephrine and serotonin transporters.
  • The resulting decreased reuptake of these neurotransmitters increases their availability in the synaptic cleft of central nervous system neurons.

Venlafaxine

  • A novel antidepressant referred to as SNRI, because it inhibits uptake of both NA and 5-HT.
  • In contrast to older TCAs
    It does not interact with cholinergic, adrenergic or histaminergic receptors or have sedative property.
  • Venlafaxine is also benefits in
    • Mood changes and hot flashes in menopausal syndrome,
    • Social anxiety and
    • Eating disorders

Option A, B & D: All other agents are not reuptake inhibitors of both 5-HT and NA.

Key Takeaway:

  • Serotonin Noradrenaline Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRI) are non-selective reuptake inhibitors of both 5-HT and NA like TCAs.
  • These include venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine (longer acting d-isomer), duloxetine, milnacipran and levo-milnacipran

questions.text: A 55-year-old man recently diagnosed with depressive disorder started an appropriate therapy with an anti-depressant drug. Which of the following agent is least likely to cause sexual side effects?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is atypical antidepressant drug hence it does not have typical sexual side effect as other anti-depressants and other agents.

Atypical Anti-Depressants

  • Have Less sexual side effects

Drugs

  • Bupropion - Anti-Smoking drug(Preferred)
  • Amineptin - ↑ Reuptake of 5-HT
  • Tianeptin - ↑ Reuptake of 5-HT
  • Vortioxetine
  • Vilazodone

Bupropion

  • This inhibitor of DA and NA uptake has excitant rather than sedative property.
  • It is metabolized into an amphetamine-like compound which can cause presynaptic release of DA and NA.
  • A sustained-release formulation is marketed as an aid to smoking cessation.
  • Bupropion may be acting by augmenting the dopaminergic reward function.

Side effects

  • Insomnia
  • Agitation
  • Dry mouth
  • Nausea
  • [No sexual side effects]

Option A, B & C: All other agents are associated with typical sexual side effects like inhibition of ejaculation and anorgasmia

Key Takeaway:

  • Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant drug hence it does not have typical sexual side effect as other anti-depressants and other agents.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complained of severe pain after surgery to remove a colon cancer. The physician prescribed a drug that is a partial μ (mu) opioid agonist more potent than morphine, and whose effects are not readily antagonized by naloxone. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
• Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and a κ (kappa) antagonist.
  • It is much more potent than morphine (0.3 mg buprenorphine is considered equianalgesic to 10 mg morphine).
  • Its effects are not readily antagonized by naloxone, likely because buprenorphine dissociates very slowly from opioid receptors

μ Receptor Functions

[Mnemonic = SACRUM]

  • S - Sedation
  • A - Analgesia
  • C - Constipation
  • R - Respiratory depression
  • U - eUphoria
  • M - Miosis

Option A, B & C: All given agents are pure opioids agonists hence their effects are readily reversed by giving naloxone.

Key Takeaway:

  • Buprenorphine's effects are not readily antagonized by naloxone, likely because buprenorphine dissociates very slowly from opioid receptors.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male drug addict patient presented to psychiatric department with symptoms like agitation and multiple tiny ulceration of skin over legs and arms. The patient also had severe itching and scratch marks on the body. Dermatological manifestations are shown in the figure below. On general examination, there is presence of tachycardia, mydriasis and hypertension. Which of the following substances is likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Cocaine produces prominent CNS stimulation with marked effect on mood and behaviour.

It induces a sense of wellbeing, delays fatigue and increases the power of endurance.

In susceptible individuals it produces a state referred to as 'high' leading to strong psychological but little physical dependence.

Cocaine is unique among drugs of abuse in not producing significant tolerance on repeated use; sometimes reverse tolerance is seen (behavioural effects are experienced at lower doses).

Cocaine blocks uptake of NA and Adr into adrenergic nerve endings

↓

Results in higher concentration of the transmitter around the receptors

↓

Sympathomimetic effect,

↓

Potentiation of directly acting sympathomimetics and suppression of indirectly acting sympathomimetics

↓

Local vasoconstriction, tachycardia, rise in BP and mydriasis

  • Cocaine induced tiny ulcerations over hands & legs are due to thrombogenic vasculitis (More if it is taken along with other adulterations)

Option A: LSD produces profound hallucinations.

Option B: Heroin (Diamorphine, Diacetylmorphine) is more potent than morphine. It is considered to be more euphoriant (especially on i.v. injection) and highly addicting.

Option D: Personality and psychiatric problems are more common among cannabis users. Young abusers may exhibit 'amotivational syndrome' i.e. loss of interest in work or self improvement activities.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine produces prominent CNS stimulation with marked effect on mood and behaviour.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man complained of severe abdominal pain after surgery to remove a kidney stone. An analgesic drug was administered intramuscularly. Shortly after the administration, an itchy weal developed at the injection site, along with generalized pruritus. Which of the following drugs was most likely given to the patient?
questions.solution:
An intramuscular injection of morphine can release histamine, which can cause a local reaction (wheal at the injection site and pruritus).

Morphine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine (due to its bulky basic molecule; the mechanism is non immunological).

This is of no consequence in normal individuals, but can be dangerous in asthmatics.

Option A, B & C: All other agents are not associated with histamine release.

Key Takeaway:

  • An intramuscular injection of morphine can release histamine, which can cause a local reaction (wheal at the injection site and pruritus).

questions.text: A 23-year-old young man with a known history of heroin addiction is brought to the emergency room in an unconscious state. On examination, the patient has decreased bowel sounds, depressed respiration, hypothermia, shallow breathing and pin point pupil. Which of the following is the best and fast onset treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The decreased bowel sounds (constipation), respiratory depression, pinpoint pupil and history of heroin addiction strongly point toward the diagnosis of acute opioid poisoning.

The drug of choice for acute opioid poisoning is intravenous naloxone.

Summary of some common antidotes used

Key Takeaway:

  • The drug of choice for acute opioid poisoning, Characterised by Respiratory depression, Constipation & Pinpoint pupil is managed with intravenous naloxone.

choices.text: Abruptio placentae and learning difficulties as the child ages
Fetal hemorrhage and defects in fetal bone formation
Microcephaly, retarded growth, and congenital heart defects

questions.text: A 28-year-old chronic alcoholic pregnant woman brought to obstetrics department for child birth. The neonatologist received history at birth that the mother did not refrain from her normal heavy alcohol binges throughout her pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of such abuse to the child after birth?
questions.solution:
Fetal alcohol syndrome is a leading cause of congenital abnormalities, especially microcephaly, growth retardation, and congenital heart defects.

Even moderate drinking during pregnancy can produce foetal alcohol syndrome resulting in

  • Intrauterine and postnatal growth retardation,
  • Low IQ offspring,
  • Microcephaly,
  • Cranio-facial (flat face) and other abnormalities,
  • Immunological impairment causing increased susceptibility to infections.

Heavy drinking during pregnancy, in addition, increases the incidence of miscarriage, still births and low birth-weight babies.

Teratogenic Drugs

Option A: Abruptio placentae and learning difficulties are more typical with maternal use of cocaine during pregnancy.

Option B: Spina bifida and orofacial defects are associated with valproic acid use during pregnancy, and the anticonvulsant phenytoin is associated with fetal growth retardation, microcephaly, and craniofacial abnormalities.

Option C: Fetal hemorrhage and bone malformation are a consequence of warfarin use during pregnancy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Alcohol Consumption during pregnancy can produce fetal alcohol syndrome characterised by Low IQ offspring, Microcephaly,Cranio-facial (flat face) and other abnormalities.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room after collapsing at a party. He complained of chest pain and an electrocardiogram demonstrated ventricular fibrillation, for which he received cardioversion. On examination the patient showed a perforated nasal septum and got the history of chronically using an illicit substance at the party. Which of the following is the most likely drug abused by him?
questions.solution:
• Cocaine is cardiotoxic and can cause arrhythmias that can be life-threatening. These effects are even more likely when alcohol is also consumed.
  • Cocaine causes vasoconstriction, and snorting the drug causes necrosis and eventual perforation of the nasal septum.

Risks of cocaine, beyond the potential for addiction

  • Cardiac arrhythmias,
  • Myocardial ischemia,
  • Myocarditis,
  • Aortic dissection,
  • Cerebral vasoconstriction, and
  • Seizures.
  • premature labor and abruptio placentae.

Chronic use is also associated with psychiatric disorders, including anxiety, depression, and psychosis.

Option A: Phencyclidine (PCP) can cause euphoria, hallucinations, an increased sense of isolation and loneliness, and increased aggression.

Option B: γ-Hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) is a barbiturate that is used as a "date rape" drug.

Option C: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) causes increased sensory awareness, perceptual distortions, and altered consciousness.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine is cardiotoxic and can cause arrhythmias that can be life-threatening.
